clinical_study.brief_title: Open Lung PEEP in Thoracic Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Individualized Open Lung PEEP in Thoracic Surgery: A Prospective Multicenter Observational Study in 17 Spanish Hospitals

lead_sponsor.agency: Fundación para la Investigación del Hospital Clínico de Valencia

clinical_study.source: Fundación para la Investigación del Hospital Clínico de Valencia

brief_summary.textblock: During thoracic surgical procedures, while ventilating with a protective tidal volume, an open lung approach consisting of a recruitment maneuver followed by an individualized positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) titrated to best respiratory system compliance (Open-lung PEEP, OL-PEEP) would decrease driving pressure. To test this hypothesis, we performed a multicenter observational study in 17 Spanish teaching hospitals of patients undergoing one lung ventilation (OLV). In addition, we analyzed the association between the driving pressure and the prevalence of postoperative pulmonary complications (PPCs), and finally the association between the individualized PEEP and relevant patient preoperative or intraoperative variables.

primary_outcome.description: Atelectasis, acute respiratory failure, ARDS, pneumonia, reintubation, empyema, bronchospasm, pneumothorax, pneumonitis, bronchopleural fistula

secondary_outcome.measure: Descriptive analysis of the open lung PEEP
secondary_outcome.description: Open lung PEEP is the PEEP of best dynamic respiratory system compliance during a PEEP titration trial

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing one lung ventilation during thoracic surgical procedures
